title: Rangkul Valley Important Bird Area
text:
The Rangkul Valley Important Bird Area is a 1612 km2 tract of land in eastern <a href="Gorno-Badakhshan%20Autonomous%20Province">Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Province</a> in eastern <a href="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>, not far from the border with <a href="China">China</a>. It contains two high altitude lakes and has been identified by <a href="BirdLife%20International">BirdLife International</a> as an <a href="Important%20Bird%20Area">Important Bird Area</a> (IBA), as well as a <a href="Ramsar%20site">Ramsar site</a>.
Description.
The Rangkul Valley is an inter-mountain trough in the eastern <a href="Pamir%20Mountains">Pamir Mountains</a> 60 km north-east of the district centre of <a href="Murghab%2C%20Tajikistan">Murghab</a>. The central part of the IBA, at an altitude of 3600–4000 m, contains two lakes, Rangkul and Shorkul, which form an <a href="Endorheic%20basin">endorheic system</a> and are connected by the Izyuk channel. Rangkul is a <a href="fresh%20water">freshwater</a> lake with an area of 8 km2 and a depth of 6 m. Shorkul is <a href="brackish">brackish</a>; it has an area of 7 km2. Both lakes freeze in winter and contain no fish, but support numerous <a href="invertebrate">invertebrate</a>s, including <a href="Gammarus">amphipods</a>, <a href="beetle">beetle</a>s and <a href="Culex">mosquito</a> <a href="larva">larva</a>e. Apart from the lakes and their <a href="littoral%20zone">littoral zone</a>s the valley is predominantly <a href="alpine%20climate">alpine</a> semi-<a href="desert">desert</a> with scattered <a href="shrub">shrub</a>s and is subject to strong winds. It is threatened by <a href="overgrazing">overgrazing</a>, which leads to increased <a href="Aeolian%20processes">wind erosion</a> and <a href="desertification">desertification</a>.
Birds.
The most favourable habitats for birdlife are along the rivers and lake shores. The site was classified as an IBA because it supports significant numbers of the populations of various bird species, either as residents, or as breeding or <a href="bird%20migration">passage migrants</a>; it has been designated as a protected <a href="Ramsar%20site">Ramsar site</a> since 2001. These include <a href="Tibetan%20snowcock">Tibetan snowcock</a>s, <a href="Himalayan%20snowcock">Himalayan snowcock</a>s, <a href="Bar-headed%20goose">bar-headed geese</a> <a href="ruddy%20shelduck">ruddy shelduck</a>s, <a href="saker%20falcon">saker falcon</a>s, <a href="Himalayan%20vulture">Himalayan vulture</a>s, <a href="lesser%20sand%20plover">lesser sand plover</a>s, <a href="brown-headed%20gull">brown-headed gull</a>s, <a href="Tibetan%20sandgrouse">Tibetan sandgrouse</a>, <a href="yellow-billed%20chough">yellow-billed chough</a>s, <a href="Hume%27s%20lark">Hume's lark</a>s, <a href="wallcreeper">wallcreeper</a>s, <a href="white-winged%20redstart">white-winged redstart</a>s, <a href="white-winged%20snowfinch">white-winged snowfinch</a>es, <a href="rufous-streaked%20accentor">rufous-streaked accentor</a>s, <a href="brown%20accentor">brown accentor</a>s, <a href="black-headed%20mountain%20finch">black-headed mountain finch</a>es, <a href="Caucasian%20great%20rosefinch">Caucasian great rosefinch</a>es and <a href="red-fronted%20rosefinch">red-fronted rosefinch</a>es.
